(1 comment)
Can we change this to always_allow or no_block
Sure, I can rename it to no_block.
Done
Why is this needed separate from the blocklist?  If devices shouldn't be on the blocklist.... just don't add them to the blocklist?  It's a compile-time written file.

I agree with you, but using a whitelist can prevent unknown devices from being accessed, which could lead to a bus lock. For example, adding devices to the CPLD or introducing 2nd or 3rd source components may require constant updates to the JSON file.

I’m not following.  an allowlist is just an opposite of a deny list.  you can represent the same thing either way.

updating the json file if you expect to change the behavior.  a whitelist doesn’t change that.

Not all devices can be accessed arbitrarily. Randomly accessing devices can easily cause the bus to lock up. An allowlist ensures that we only need to list FRU devices, without having to enumerate every device that "might" be accessed. This significantly reduces the need for extensive listing.

This is Harma blacklist.
https://github.com/openbmc/openbmc/blob/master/meta-facebook/meta-harma/recipes-phosphor/configuration/entity-manager/blacklist.json

If we use address_white, we only need to configure it as follows:

...
8,
{
  "bus": 9,
  "addresses_white": [ "0x52"]
},
10,
{
  "bus": 11,
  "addresses_white": [ "0x52"]
},
12,
...
Done

>  up. An allowlist ensures that we only need to list FRU devices, without having to enumerate every device that "might" be accessed. This significantly reduces the need for extensive listing.

Sorry, this doesn't answer the question.  

> If we use address_white, we only need to configure it as follows:


This same configuration is perfectly representable in the blocklist, by blocking ranges 0x00-0x51 and 0x53-0xFF.
Could you provide an example of blocking ranges configuration in blacklist.json?

Hi Ed,
  Would you like to modify the blacklist to support range configurations, or do we currently have this feature supported?
Can you update blacklist_configuration.md?
Commit message needs updated with more explanation as to "why" this is needed.
Sure.
Done.
It would be good to specify you're adding it to blacklist.json here.
Done
nit: strange line break here.
Done
I don't follow this.  Why wouldn't the bus be blocked if all that's in the JSON is the bus number?
Done
how about 'allow'.  Also, can leave off the Set since that's just the data type.
Done
this strips the 0x?  what if it doesn't start with one?
Done
since 3 and 0x77 are used elsewhere in the file, how about make a constant for them.
Done
can just use !addresses.contains()
Done

Hi Ed,
Do you have any other concerns regarding this commit?
"allowlist"
Since the opposite behavior is "addresses", I don't think "no_block" is very intuitive.  How about "only_addresses"?  Not sure if others have opinions.
Do we have comments on why these are the minimum and maximum addresses?
Can we combine the two legs of this to simplify?  There is a lot of duplicated code and it is now almost 100 lines long.
